title: Mikaela K. Nishida
text:
Hello! I am a fifth-year Statistics Ph.D. Candidate at the University of California, Irvine. I am currently working on developing robust methods for censored, time-to-event data. I am mentored by Drs. Daniel Gillen (UCI) and Michelle Nuño (USC), and I am also a member of the research lab led by Drs. Daniel Gillen and Joshua Grill (UCI), which focuses on applications in Alzheimer’s disease recruitment and retention.
I am originally from Honolulu, Hawai‘i. My hobbies include swimming, going to the beach, and trying new restaurants.

title: Research
text:
I work on the development of statistical methodology in survival analysis along with applied research problems in Alzheimer’s disease recruitment and retention science.

Statistical Methodology
My methodological research involves developing statistical methods to increase efficiency while maximizing information on underrepresented populations through efficient sampling designs. This work is highly motivated by current challenges in Alzheimer’s disease biomarker discovery, including the challenges with representative participation and data collection costs. My recent work involves weighted sampling under the nested case-control (NCC) design to increase precision for estimating subpopulation-specific biomarker effects in secondary analyses. I am currently working on extensions for implementation of the NCC design in the multiple event setting along with censoring-robust inference in the multiple event setting.

Publications
(Under review) Nishida, M.K., Nuño, M.M., Gillen, D.L., “Modified Nested Case-Control Designs for Assessing Effect Modification in Underrepresented Subpopulations.”
(In preparation) Nishida, M.K., Nuño, M.M., Gillen, D.L., “Nested Case-Control Sampling for Marginal Estimation in Multiple Event Settings.”





Applied Statistics
I am a part of a research lab that focuses on answering important questions in Alzheimer’s disease recruitment and retention science, including the barriers to enrollment for a diverse set of participants and the ethical implications of recruitment strategies. I have collaborated with colleagues to explore how informant replacement, or the change in a participant’s study partner, impacts bias and variance in trial outcome measures, and I am currently working on looking at the utility of different recruitment strategies across a diverse sample.

Publications
Nishida, M.K., Nuño, M.M., Grill, J.D., Gillen, D.L., “Effects of Informant Replacement in Alzheimer’s Disease Clinical Trials.” Alzheimer’s & Dementia: Translational Research & Clinical Interventions (2023). https://doi.org/10.1002/trc2.12439
Nishida, M.K., Nuño, M.M., Grill, J.D., Gillen, D.L., “Impacts of Informant Replacement in Two Industry-Sponsored Alzheimer’s Disease Clinical Trials.” Alzheimer’s & Dementia: Translational Research & Clinical Interventions (2024). https://doi.org/10.1002/trc2.70009
